The following individuals must be subject to criminal background and sex offender registry checks:

  • All university employees (via Human Resources)
  • University sponsored child-related [TERM Programs]The term “program” includes ongoing or planned events that are designed to include children such as camps, lessons, workshops, clubs, teams, projects, practices, tours, or open-houses.[/TERM] must ensure that all University employees, students and volunteers who will work with children have been subject to a criminal background check within the last five years. Sex offender registry checks must be repeated annually. All University employees, students and volunteers who work with children must fully disclose all such convictions.
  • Examples of programs include:
    [IMG canstockphoto7124591.jpg]
    • Camps
    • Lessons
    • Workshops
    • Clubs
    • Teams
    • Projects
    • Practices
    • Open-houses

• Programs are prohibited from including individuals with a record of sexually-based offenses or crimes against children.
  • In regards to individuals whose records show offenses of a different nature, program directors should consult the following to determine if those offenses should preclude participation:
    • Dean of Students,
    • Campus Human Resources Office,
    • Academic Affairs, or
    • The University Director of Public Safety

• Exceptions are in place for programs that are occasional and need a large number of volunteers:
    • These programs may elect to adopt measures and safeguards instead of background checks for the one-time volunteers (for example, First Lego League, area school camps, children's reading/activity days, etc.).
    • The measures adopted must include requirements that the volunteers be working in public places, not alone with children, and be supervised by a background-checked person.
    • Programs must compile the names and addresses of the volunteers prior to the event and check the names against the sex offender registry.
    • Volunteers must then present photo identification to be checked at the event.
    • Programs adopting this method must have the approval of the University Child Protection Committee.
